html:
Etymology[edit]

From re- (“back, again”) +‎ dūcō (“lead”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /reˈduː.koː/, [rɛˈd̪uː.koː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /reˈdu.ko/, [rɛˈd̪uː.kɔ]

Verb[edit]

redūcō (present infinitive redūcere, perfect active redūxī, supine reductum); third conjugation, irregular short imperative

  1. I lead, draw, bring or conduct back; bring or accompany home
  2. (military, of troops) I withdraw, cause to retreat, draw off, remove
  3. (figuratively) I bring back, restore, recall, revive, replace; reform
  4. (figuratively) I bring, produce or get out a quantity of
  5. (figuratively) I bring, make or reduce to a certain condition or quality
  6. (Medieval Latin) I quell, I subdue, I subjugate [10th C.]

Synonyms[edit]

  • (I subjugate): subiugō (Classical)

Derived terms[edit]

  • reductiō
  • reductō
  • reductor
  • reductus
  • redux

Related terms[edit]

  • abdūcō
  • addūcō
  • circumdūcō
  • condūcō
  • dēdūcō
  • dīdūcō
  • dūcō
  • ēdūcō
  • indūcō
  • intrōdūcō
  • obdūcō
  • perdūcō
  • praedūcō
  • praeterdūcō
  • prōdūcō
  • sēdūcō
  • subdūcō
  • subterdūcō
  • superdūcō
  • trānsdūcō

Descendants[edit]

  • Asturian: reducir
  • Catalan: reduir
  • English: reduce
  • French: réduire
  • Friulian: ridusi
  • Italian: ridurre
  • Ladin: redujer, reduje
  • Occitan: redusir, reduire
  • Piedmontese: ridùe
  • Portuguese: reduzir
  • Romanian: reduce, arăduce
  • Romansch: reducir, reduzir, redutgier, redüer
  • Sicilian: arridùciri, arriddùciri
  • Spanish: reducir
  • Venetian: ridùxer, redùxe, redùr, ridùr

References[edit]

  • reduco in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • reduco in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • reduco in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
  • Carl Meissner; Henry William Auden (1894) Latin Phrase-Book‎[1], London: Macmillan and Co.
    • to reconcile two people; to be a mediator: in gratiam aliquem cum aliquo reducere
    • to recall a thing to a person's mind: in memoriam alicuius redigere, reducere aliquid (not revocare)
    • to bring a person back to the right way: in viam reducere aliquem
    • to reduce a people to their former obedience: aliquem ad officium (cf. sect. X. 7, note officium...) reducere (Nep. Dat. 2. 3)
  • Jan Frederik Niermeyer, Mediae Latinitatis Lexicon Minus : Lexique Latin Médiéval–Français/Anglais : A Medieval Latin–French/English Dictionary, fascicle I (1976), 898/1, “reducere”
